item.title: A pilot's heroic rescue of 51 men.
item.description:
During his second tour of duty in Vietnam, Major (later Major General) Patrick Henry Brady, was assigned to the 54th Medical Detachment – Helicopter Ambulance. While commanding a UH-1H ambulance helicopter, Brady flew dangerous rescue missions deep in enemy-held territory which was heavily defended and often blanketed by dense fog.
On January 6, 1968, Brady was off duty but volunteered to rescue wounded men from four sites in enemy territory. Throughout that day, Brady utilized three helicopters to evacuate a total of 51 seriously wounded men. For these actions, he was awarded the Medal of Honor.

item.title: The legacy of Lt. Col. George Hardy.
item.description:
We’re saddened to learn that our friend, Lt. Col. George Hardy, who was the last surviving Tuskegee Airmen to fly combat missions, passed away on September 25, 2025 at the age of 100.
The Tuskegee Airmen were a group of primarily African-American military pilots and airmen who fought in World War II. Before the Tuskegee Airmen, no African American had ever been a United States military pilot.
Hardy deployed in early 1945 to Italy joining the African American 99th Fighter Squadron, 332nd Fighter Group. He flew 21 combat missions over Germany and occupied Europe piloting P-51 Mustang aircraft, often escorting heavy bombers. Following World War II, Hardy flew 45 combat missions during the Korean War as the pilot of a bomber and 70 missions piloting an AC-119K gunship during the Vietnam War.

item.title: Honoring the women warriors of Special Forces.
item.description:
Remembering when the Distinguished Women Warriors of the U.S. Special Operation Forces were honored at American Valor.
For the past 28 years the AVC has brought together dozens of notable veterans of the last 80 years of history for our Annual Veterans Conference, where they share their lessons and experiences with an audience of several hundred students from each of the military service academies & ROTC programs from across the country. Participants range from surviving heroes of WWII to recipients of the Medal of Honor to young Special Operations veterans of today’s military. The weekend of programming concludes with American Valor: A Salute to Our Heroes, a black-tie gala filmed as a Veterans Day television special, airing on ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox stations across the country, and to all military personnel around the world on American Forces Network. We look forward to our 28th Annual Conference & Gala this coming November!

item.title: Happy 105th Birthday to a WWII Hero.
item.description:
Wishing Major Fannie Griffin McClendon a Happy 105th Birthday! She spent more than two decades in the military including serving as a squadron commander in the Air Force. She is the last surviving member of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion.
This Battalion was the first and only all-female African American unit deployed overseas during WWII. They were sent to Birmingham, England and then to Rouen, France to sort through the two year backlog of undelivered mail destined for the men on the front.

item.title: The day the 101st Airborne escorted the Little Rock Nine.
item.description: During this month back in 1957, nine students known as the iconic ‘Little Rock Nine,’ were integrated into Little Rock Central High School following Brown v. Board of Education. These students were escorted to school by paratroopers of the 101st Airborne Division, at the order of President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Carlotta Walls LaNier was one of those nine students and we had the pleasure to sit down with her back in 2021.
